Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The industrial relations debate is now well under way and substantial contributions are being made by members on this side of the House in exposing the unfairness of this legislation. It is an iterative unfairness, as one clause relates to another basically to deprive ordinary Australians of their standing in the Australian workplace, making it easy to crush their wages and conditions and leaving them cowered in the workplace. Particularly in a period of time when there is any form of economic softening or downturn, many will then find themselves in a situation where they will not be able to sustain their mortgages and will not be able to sustain those things that make them happy in life, especially the relationships that they have with their families, so essentially served by decent hours of workand decent holidays-and a capacity to have those hours reflect the fact that there is time for children and time for spouses. We have been demonstrating that amply and clearly over the course of the last part of this day. I am going to focus a little later in these remarks on what has been discovered, to the surprise of many, about the character of the unfair dismissal laws, which of course lie at the basis of the capacity of the worker to be intimidated by the employer in any bargaining that takes place with regard to AWAs and-it has to be said-in any general conduct in the workplace. I am going to concentrate on that somewhat. But what I want to concentrate on before I do that is going to the heart of what seems to be the ‘answer' being offered to our side of the House by our political opponents as to why they do the things they do. Their election campaign is a cloud of deceit. The campaign around their advertising is a cloud of deceit-a pretence that there is protection going on of workers' rights. But in the end they know in their heart of hearts that is not true, so they go to the last trench. last trench and the last ditch in every one of the contributions I have heard so far is that somehow or other what is being done here is essential for the Australian economy. I want to nail that in five quick minutes here before I get on to the unfair dismissal issues. The simple fact of the matter is this: to improve the productivity of the work force, the Reserve Bank, the OECD and all economic commentators have had the following to say about our slowing rate of labour productivity growth. They have said it is a matter of skills-the skilling of the Australian work force. The finger is firmly pointed at the fective collapse of the resourcing of skills training which has occurred in our schools, TAFEs and universities over the last decade-not simply by the Labor Party but by all those relevant bodies that commentate on the Australian economy. The second thing which is pointed to by those who analyse our economy is the absence of decent central direction and central leadership of the development of Australia's infrastructure and, in particular, the removal of bottlenecks to exports. That has also drawn the attention of everybody who analyses the character of the Australian economy. The third thing that is raised is innovation, particularly business investment in research and development. Until very recently, most of the massive burgeoning of the foreign debt of this country-which in itself places pressure on interest rates and our international competitiveness-went into borrowings for consumption here and not for business investment in research and development, which absolutely collapsed when this government came to office. These commentators also point in particular to the fact that we have a very substantial burden that arrives on judgments about our economy because of our balance of payments. Finally, there is a discussion of the export performThe ance, particularly the export performance related to value-added production in manufacturing and new services. When the Labor Party were in office those exports were growing at a rate of 10 to 15 per cent per annum under very effective industry plans to encourage Australian businesses to go down the road of world's best practice. We added one thing to this when we were in office-there was also a much better picture on all these fronts when we were there, which produced the substantial growth in labour productivity in our economy through the late nineties and into the early ef- part of this century-and that was the changes we made to the industrial relations system, which were not related to the exercise of negotiation of individual contracts by businesses in this country but were related to the possibility of enterprise bargaining. This means collective agreements arrived at at the level of the firm or the enterprise and where every few years employers and employees sat down and bargained productivity based wage rises. It is precisely those productivity based wage rises that have produced the relatively good figures on real wage increases over the course of the last decade. But the truth of the matter is that all that fell in a hole a couple of years ago. The government's answer is not to go down the road of improving the skills of our work force to improve our performance and our international competitiveness. It is not to deal with our infrastructure problems or to deal with problems of innovation. It is not to deal with its shocking export performance, when despite the best terms of trade this nation has ever had we have the worse export performance since World War II. No, it does not go to deal with that. The Prime Minister comes into this place and tries to bamboozle the Australian public with this statement: ‘The only thing we can do to compete with India and China is to suppress our wage rates so that we come down somewhere near where they are. We hope to meet them on the way up, coming down. We race to the bottom and they race to the top and at some point we will intersecthopefully with a basic capacity to sustain the necessary calories for daily life. But, apart from that, we are not interested in anything else.' This is an absolutely monstrous deceit, and the Australian public are getting sick of this tricky Prime Minister and his tricky Treasurer. They are getting alive to this tricky Prime Minister and this tricky Treasurer, even to the point of disbelieving them on occasions when perhaps they ought to be believed. But I do not talk about that in the context of anything related to the industrial relations act, as they ought not to be believed about anything there. You saw the example of that trickiness in question time when the Prime Minister, with a smirk, got up today. He was asked a question by the member for Throsby-a former President of the ACTU, and we are very pleased to have her within our ranks. Indeed, she was the first woman to be President of the ACTU and is a great servant of the needs of ordinary people in this country. She asked the Prime Minister-going through each of his election manifestos-in which of them did he talk about making it easy to sack people or removing unfair dismissal laws from employers of a particular number of employees in a firm. At what point did the Prime Minister, in his election campaign propaganda, say that the size of the firm that would determine the application of the removal of that unfair dismissal law was 100 employees? He got up in this chamber and said, ‘If you look really hard at what we had to say in our manifesto, we didn't actually put any number there.' And he smiled, with that little smirk: ‘Ha, ha, tricked you! Ha, ha, we tricked the Australian people again-whacko, we got ‘em!' ‘We might have moved 30 times in the House, in the run-up to the election, in relation to a bill which put the limit at 20 employees. We might have done that, but we did not put it in the fine line in our election propaganda'-it is all very tricky! It was the ‘kids overboard' in the previous election and this time it was the ‘employees overboard', by sleight of hand, as far as this government was concerned. It is important to focus on this issue, and I conclude on one point. What this is all leading to is a set of work practices and relationships in our industry which will do major damage to the Australian economy. How do we know that it will do major damage to the Australian economy? Because we have the comparative basis of the New Zealand legislation from 1991 that the government is so fond of quoting and the changes that the Hawke-Keating governments put in place. We addressed the productivity issue on the basis of collective agreements, organised on the basis of the firm. In New Zealand, they eliminated collective agreements, awards and the like and reduced everything to individual contracts. Until that point in time, the rate of productivity growth in the work force in New Zealand and Australia had been exactly the same for 15 years. We have a decade's comparison on the period since then, and the rate of productivity growth in the Australian work force has been twice that in New Zealand. New Zealand, in addressing the problems that emerged in their economy, went back to look at their acts-and the Clark government has changed the basis of these acts, having seen the appalling performance, in terms of productivity in the work force, that the road the previous government chose to go down managed to produce. This government will poleaxe the Australian economy with what it proposes here, not enhance the Australian economy. It will effectively eliminate from firms that process by which workers and employers sit down collectively and talk through the productivity needs of a firm, and it will replace it by a race to the bottom by employers around this country, as they compete to see how much they can deprive their individual workers on an individual basis of what it is that they have. At the heart of all of that lies the unfair dismissal laws-the capacity to make it easy to sack somebody. The deceit that we have seen in the advertising campaign was repeated by the Prime Minister here today. On reading the papers, from the comments from various legal experts, we discovered that the 100-employee figure probably does not mean much, either, and that in fact you can do things artificially in a way that means that people employed in every type of firm can effectively be subject to unfair dismissal laws. We discovered that as a result of those very careful pieces of analyses. In his answer, the Prime Minister went back to the same mechanism that the government have used in their advertising campaign to answer the ACTU's ‘funded by the workers' advertising campaign-to answer the union's proposition that your rights against being unfairly dismissed are no longer protected by law-and that is to the very difficult to prove unlawful dismissal process. This requires proving in a court an issue of discrimination on ethnic, racial or whatever grounds. That being protected by law is the cover-all for a massive change on the unfair dismissal front. The Prime Minister retreated to that today by instantly going off an argument based on unfair dismissals for operational purposes to unlawful dismissals for discrimination purposes. It is a complex point but with a simple outcome, and the simple outcome is: everybody is now easy to sack. It is essential to make everybody easy to sack because, unless they are easy to sack, they are likely to seek protection from a union or may even stand you up in an AWA inquiry. I thought one of the quotes from a lawyer from Blake Dawson Waldron-one of the 11 companies that was set down to draft this legislation-was terribly interesting. I will conclude with this quote, in which she said: The legislation appeared to allow employers with existing certified agreements to offer AWAs that overrode existing employment arrangements. The legislation is making it as easy as possible for employers to directly set the terms and conditions of employment. It is a deceit that the Prime Minister went on with about redundancy payments or whatever. Redundancy payments can go from your individual agreements, and ‘operational' means that the boss can sack you if he has found somebody who will work for a few bucks less. It is all right to sack you operationally because it is getting near Christmas or it is after Christmas and the business is quiet. It is all right to sack you because you would not go out and buy your boss's lunch operationally. It is all right to sack you because the boss does not like your attitude operationally, and it is all right to sack you because the boss just does not like you. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Menzies-Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service) (3.38 pm)-There is no greater irony than when we see the previous speaker in this debate-the man who was part of a government that drove one million Australians into unemployment-come here and talk about the threat to the employment security of Australians. This is the man who was part of a government whose economic record included the reduction of real wages for ordinary men and women working in Australia-and he walks out of the chamber, of course. He does not want to hear his record repeated to him: the reduction in the real wages of the ordinary working men and women of Australia. That is what the Leader of the Opposition was partly responsible for when he was a senior minister in the Hawke and the Keating governments. Not only that, when he talks about employment security, that was a government that brought about the ‘recession we had to have'-to use the infamous words of the former Prime Minister, Mr KEATING - and, in doing so, drove into unemployment one million Australians. That is the record that ought to be brought back to the Leader of the Opposition when he has the gall to talk today, as he did, about the threat to the employment security of working Australians. The reality is that the only person who has been in government in this chamber who has had something to do in historic terms with driving down the economic security and the employment security of Australians is the Leader of the Opposition when he was a senior minister in the Hawke and the Keating governments. What gall! The reality is the record of this government, in the face of tooth-and-nail opposition day after day in this parliament for the last 9½ years, which has brought about a situation in which we have seen the creation of 1.7 million jobs-a fact. Look at the Australian Bureau of Statistics in relation to the creation of jobs in Australia. It is a fact out by the national accounts. As the Treasurer said today, we have seen a 15 per cent increase in real wages for the working men and women of Australia. That compares with a miserly 1.2 per cent increase in real wages under the 13 years in which the Labor Party was in government-and the Leader of the Opposition talks today about economic and employment security for Australians. His track record is abysmal, and he cannot come in here and lecture us about the economic and employment security of Australians when we are the government that have actually seen the creation of those jobs and, through good economic management, have seen an increase in real wages of some 15 per cent over the last 9½ years in Australia. The reality about this campaign from the opposition this week is, as we said at the outset, that it has been a hysterical campaign in which we have seen increasing desperation on the part of the opposition-highlighted by some of the antics that we saw in question time today with I think nearly two dozen, at last count, Labor members being thrown out of this House for the disorderly conduct which they were engaging in. This is a desperate measure by the Leader of the Opposition and the Labor Party. We see this hysterical campaign highlighted by grubby little antics-by the member for Perth removing copies of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005 from the table yesterday, giving them to people to take out of the parliament and then complaining and making a point of order that copies of the bill were not here. He was caught out on that. He knows it. Even his explanation today gave it away when he said, ‘There weren't 60 copies.' What was pointed about that, and what he did not say, was how many copies he actually removed. He knows that he removed copies, yet we had this grubby little antic yesterday. This shows once again the borne desperation that the opposition has engaged in and the hysterical sort of campaign that we have had from the Leader of the Opposition and others in relation to these particular measures. Let us turn to the detail of some of the things which the Leader of the Opposition has been raising. Even in terms of the detail, he is wrong. Yesterday afternoon, within hours of the Work Choices bill being tabled, he had to retract. The Leader of the Opposition was out saying that, if a worker spoke about or disclosed to somebody else the fact that they were on an Australian workplace agreement, there was a penalty that would apply to them under the legislation of up to six months imprisonment. He was wrong. He had to come out yesterday afternoon and concede, on the first point he raised in relation to detail of this legislation, that he wrong. We see continued misrepresentation of the legislation today by the Leader of the Opposition. For example, we had this point about the question of whether somebody has to take an AWA as a condition of employment. In parliament the member for Perth, Mr Smith, said, ‘Either you take the AWA as a condition of employment or you do not get or keep your job.' That is totally wrong. There is no amendment to section 170CK(2)(g), if the member for Perth would like to look at it. The act makes it clear an existing employee cannot be forced-it is unlawful to force an existing employee to take an Australian workplace agreementyet speaker after speaker from the Labor Party in the debate in this House has been making that wrong point about the legislation. That is two things that they are wrong on. Today we had this question about dismissal for operational reasons. There are in the existing law provisions that a person can be made redundant for what are generally known as operational reasons, and that has been replicated in this legislation. But let just put forward the contention that in effect has been advanced by the opposition. They are saying that you could be made redundant for genuine reasons-as you can be now, as you will be in the future-and you can get a redundancy payout under your award or under the agreement under which that redundancy provision is. Yet the opposition are contending that, further to that, a worker should be able to double-dip in the system and also claim further compensation for an unfair dismissal. That is what this amounts to. The moral of this is that the opposition is saying that a worker can get their proper entitlements under redundancy provisions but then come back and double-dip from the emwas ployer by being paid out under unfair dismissals as well. That is the reality of the contention which is being advanced by the opposition in relation to this. I believe-as the government believes-that ordinary Australian workers would say that if you are entitled to redundancy payouts and redundancy provisions then that is fair; that is appropriate. But beyond that you should not have the right to come back and say, ‘I should get an unfair dismissal on top of that,' effectively double-dipping from the employer. What would be the effect of that? The effect of that that would be to take money from the employer that could be used for other purposes, including possibly an increase in wages for other employees of that particular firm or putting on somebody else in the future to do some other job where there is a demand for that job. That is the contention that is being advanced by the opposition in relation to this today. On the first three matters of detail which the opposition raise in relation to this legislation they are wrong. They are wrong on those three matters of detail. The Leader of the Opposition has had to concede that the me first matter he raised was wrong. He ought to come out now and concede that the other two matters of detail which he raised were wrong. The opposition ought to actually look at the bill and look at the act which it is amending before they come out with further nonsensical claims. Otherwise one could only come to the conclusion that the reason for advancing these claims has nothing to do with the debate about the bill; it is simply furthering the scaremongering campaign that has been undertaken by the opposition and the labour movement to date. The reality is that these reforms are important to Australia. One of the things which the Labor Party does not seem to have learnt-and which, to his credit, Paul Keating learnt in the early 1990s-is that a rigid labour market in Australia will not protect people from unemployment if the economy is not strong. We had a rigid labour market in the late 1980s and early 1990s in Australia but that did not stop the recession at the end of the 1980s. It did not stop one million people being driven into unemployment. Belatedly, Paul Keating recognised that and started the process which we are continuing today-that is, the move away from the rigidities of the old award system towards the agreement-making system. As I told the parliament yesterday, it really pays to read the speech that Paul Keating made to the Australian Institute of Company Directors in 1993, when he said that the model which he envisioned for Australia was one which placed the primary emphasis on bargaining at the workplace level within a framework of minimum standards. He went on to say: It is a model under which compulsorily arbitrated awards and arbitrated wages increases would be there only as a safety net. The safety net would not be intended to prescribe the actual conditions of work of most employees, but only to catch those unable to make workplace agreements with employers. He went on after that. That was what Paul Keating set out, and what he started to enact back in 1993. As I recall it, he did that against the opposition of the then labour movement in Australia. We all remember those scenes at the Sydney Town Hall, when Laurie Brereton, as Minister for Industrial Relations in the Keating government, advanced those propositions and was shouted down by the labour movement. Keating and Brereton and others at that time had the courage to move on some of these things. What we are doing is taking an evolutionary step based on that which was begun in 1993 and continued in 1996. We are taking further steps in that now. The Leader of the Opposition said today, ‘Nobody of any economic note makes out a case for further economic reform.' I am not sure whom he has been reading or not reading, and whom he has been listening to or not listening to, but the IMF, the OECD, the Reserve Bank of Australia and Access Economics-a whole series of people whose views on this matter are not only creditable but based on detailed analysis of the situation-have said that there is a case for further economic reform in industrial relations because that will contribute to an increase in productivity in Australia. If the Leader of the Opposition wants the latest piece of evidence he should look at the 2004-05 annual report of the Productivity Commission, which was issued just a couple of days ago. In summary, the Productivity Commission says that further reforms to industrial relations in Australia are necessary if we want to increase productivity. The Productivity Commission has already pointed out that we will have to rely over the next four or five decades on increased productivity if we want to sustain economic growth and therefore the economic prosperity of this nation. In this latest report it says that if we can raise our productivity it could be worth as much as $22,000 a year in the pockets of householders in Australia. Gross average household income could be 20 per cent or some $22,000 a year higher. What Australian would not want the opportunity to have an increase in their gross household income of some $22,000? Yet the Labor Party, because it is dominated by the vested interests of the unions in Australia, stands against what could be to the advantage of the ordinary men and women of this country. When the Prime Minister and others on this side say that we are supporting the men and women of Australia, and that we are doing it in the face of the opposition of the Labor Party, it is only too true. The other matter is that what seems to have escaped the opposition in this entire debate is the simple moral principle that all Australians who want to work should be able to get a job. We heard the Leader of the Opposition banging on in question time today about fairness. He was asking where the word ‘fairness' was in relation to the Australian Fair Pay Commission. In relation to the objectives of the Australian Fair Pay Commission the bill says it should have regard to the following: (a) the capacity for the unemployed and low paid to obtain and remain in employment; The first step in fairness is to be able to job. That is something that a modern Labour leader like Tony Blair recognised. And he had the courage to tell that to the Trades Union Congress when he was first elected as Prime Minister of Great Britain. Fairness surely starts with the capacity of someone to get a job in this country. What is so difficult with that proposition that this Labor Partythis party which has its historic roots in representing the working men and women of Australia-cannot see that today? Surely that moral principle, which stands at the base of fairness, ought to be one which is accepted by everybody in this House and everybody throughout Australia. Beyond that, the objectives include providing a safety net for the low paid. Isn't providing a safety net for the low paid a fundamental principle of fairness? Yet, the Leader of the Opposition banged on in this place in question time today in the overly desperate, increasingly desperate and hysterical way that he does that somehow there is no fairness in this system. The moral principle which was outlined by the Prime Minister, which was outlined by Tony Blair when he spoke to the Trades Union Congress, is a very fundamental one. We on this side of the House will support it and continue to support it. For those 700,000 kids who are in homes across Australia where no-one has got a job, I would say that fairness would be getting a job. That is something which they would want, which their parents would want and which we are on about. It is a great pity that the Australian Labor Party has lost any sense of representing the working men and women of Australia and that it has totally abandoned those who do not have a job. It is shameful.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: There is something especially obscene about the government's $55 million get a propaganda campaign being paid for by the taxes of the very people it intends to hurt. There is also something particularly perverse about a government punishing the very people who have built the country's economy and who have ensured economic growth for 14 consecutive years. Although I should be surprised, I am not surprised that there is something duplicitous and dishonest about the government's depiction of the Work Choices bill and its consequences for the working men and women of this country. I am not the least surprised that there is something ultimately tragic about the government's willingness to tear apart workplaces, to pit worker against worker and to demolish decent employment conditions in order to annihilate the trade union movement in this country. We on this side of the House are not surprised, because this has been the Prime Minister's ambition for more than 30 years. The modus operandi of the government is to tell lies, repeat the lies ad nauseam and, if possible, use the taxpayers' money to do it. That is effectively what the government has done with this legislation: say one thing, do another. The opposition leader today quoted George Orwell's description of political deception. But the Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005, which has been introduced into the House, is not the first time that Orwellian language has been adopted to lie to an unsuspecting public. For nine years, the government has bent and turned the English language upside down, on its head, to deceive Australian working families. One example of that is a term in a bill introduced in 1996 called ‘Australian workplace agreements'. Australian? What is intrinsically Australian about Australian workplace agreements? Nothing. They are in fact foreign to the intrinsic nature of the industrial relations system in this country. Then there is the word ‘workplace'. How can an AWA be a workplace agreement? It is an individual contract. Finally, there is the word ‘agreement'. How many AWAs are actually made genuinely by agreement? They are usually imposed upon the employees of this country. Indeed, after nine years of deception and coercion, having failed to achieve pushing more than four per cent of the Australian work force onto AWAs, the government has decided to create a set of laws that will expressly allow for employers to require employees to sign AWAs. Effectively, employees of this country have said no to Australian workplace agreements. That is why such a negligible proportion of the Australian work force have chosen to take those contracts. The government will force them by putting in the proposed legislation that it is not duress for an employer to require his or her employee to sign an AWA-the government calls that an agreement. The government calls that set of laws ‘work choices'. We know that there is no choice in the Work Choice legislation being proposed to this House. The MPI today, proposed by the Leader of the Opposition, is about the threat of this legislation to the employment security of ordinary working Australian families. Already this country has the most casualised work force amongst OECD nations and, under this government, that trend is likely to continue unabated. Many people in casual jobs have permanent family responsibilities. Many people in short-term jobs have long-term mortgages. The Work Choice bill seeks to undermine the certainty and security of Australians in their workplaces. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005 is moving the pendulum so far in favour of employers that it is designed to make workers afraid. It is designed to make workers afraid to stand up and say, ‘I want a say in how my working conditions can be applied every day in my workplace.' Over the days, weeks and months ahead, the pernicious nature of this bill will become known to millions of Australians. There are many examples that I could cite to underline its unprecedented extremism, but I will confine myself to one. Under this legislation, if enacted, an employee could be told that they have to accept moving from, say, an eighthour day shift from Monday to Friday to working Saturday, Sunday, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. The employer could say: ‘Now that's your five-day week and, while we're on it, we might as well move you to the evening shift. We'll make you work Saturday to Wednesday. We'll make it an evening shift.' Would the employer have to provide a penalty? Ms George-No.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Not at all. Would the employer have to offer any compensation to that employee? Not at all. By the way, that is not even an extreme example of what could occur in the event of this bill being enacted. What we have in this legislation are very extreme laws. I know that it is sometimes customary in MPIs for us to use hyperbole to make a point, but I can tell you that it is very difficult to exaggerate the consequences of the Work Choices bill introduced into the House this week. The fact is that, by removing the no disadvantage test, by removing the capacity for employees to be protected, employers in this country will be able to remove the conditions of employment-the standards that have been accepted over many decades in this country. I would like to refer to an example used in the government's 65 pages of propaganda on Work Choices. Indeed, the Prime Minister himself raised the example of Billy. I think we are all beginning to get to know Billy a little. Billy is an unemployed job seeker who is offered a full-time job as a job assistant by Costas who owns a clothing retail store in Canberra. … … … The AWA Billy is offered provides him with the relevant minimum award classification wage and explicitly removes other award conditions. … … … The AWA Billy is offered explicitly removes award conditions for public holidays, rest breaks, bonuses, annual leave loadings, allowances, penalty rates and shift/overtime loadings. Effectively, somebody who is currently unemployed can be offered five minimum conditions, and the Prime Minister boasts about it. Let me say this: I know there will be some in this community who may think that providing an unemployed person with a job is a decent thing to do. I know there might be some people in the community who would say it is better than being unemployed. But let me examine that example of Billy. Say the employer offers that set of conditions to Billy and Billy takes up employment as a new employee in that retail store. What do you think then happens to Billy's workmates? What sorts of pressures do you think are on them to undermine their own conditions to keep their work? If an employer is willing to impose such an unfair thing on a vulnerable person like an unemployed worker, then he is just as likely to do it to his existing employees. Once Billy is in that workplace, that will be the benchmark for the future, particularly if the economy is suffering a downturn. And what happens to the honourable employer who has the shop up the road and competes against that company? That employer, who gets on well with his employees, will call a meeting of his workers and say: ‘I'm terribly sorry, but the fact is this: the competitor down the road has a bloke called Billy who is employed under a certain set of conditions. As a result, his workmates have chosen to take his conditions rather than lose their jobs. I don't want to lose my store, so to ensure that you are employed you will have to do the same.' That is basically the story of Billy. That is why all workers in this country should be worried, because this legislation is about a race to the bottom. But it is a race we cannot win against China and India, as the Leader of the Opposition said. So we must instead focus on skills, on training and on ensuring that our greatest asset in this country-our work force-is looked after. We need to ensure that we work collaboratively with employees, not turn them against each other, and that we do not turn honourable employers against their own employees. That is what this government is choosing to do. This Prime Minister has had a 30-year obsession with destroying workers' conditions and trade unions in this country, and we will not let it happen. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mrs BRONWYN BISHOP
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have listened with interest to the arguments that have been made in the chamber and I must say I have heard a lot of huffing and puffing but not much substance. If we look at what this argument is truly about, it is a disagreement of philosophy. It is a disagreement between those who want to see individuals succeed, the nation prosper and wage control centralised, and those who want to see total control of individuals by a would be collectivist government. That would mean they would have under their control the workplace environment that has gained them some $47 million from trade unions between 1995-96 and today. This argument is not really about employment security but about pocket security for the ALP and a strong trade union movement which delivers money into the coffers of the ALP. When I look for the views of other Labor figures, I see that Steve Bracks, the Victorian ALP Premier, supports in principle the concept of a single national system of industrial relations and always has. He said: It can deliver benefits to both employees and employers by creating a uniform national framework for dispute resolution and the application of minimum employment standards that can be more easily complied with and enforced. Even Stephen Smith, the member for Perth, said as latterly as 20 February: It is possible to consider, in the abstract or thetically, a single or a unitary system. It's novel policy idea, and you can contemplate a whole range of efficiencies that would occur in the economy and in the system if that were to take place. What happened that he changed his mind between February this year and today? It is because of the loss of control by collectivist governments of individuals who want to work in a way that suits them. The concept of an employer and an employee negotiating together for an outcome that suits them is one that has been a long time coming but is one that will serve this country well. It was only after we saw the first workplace reforms in 1996 that productivity started to grow in Australia. We had been behind the OECD productivity growth figures for decades. The thing that always held us back was a rigid work force situation, where we did not get the best productivity from individual workers and they did not get their best rewards. We have heard statements made again and again by this government and they are worth repeating: since we have been in office and seen the first tranche of workplace reform put in place, 1.7 million jobs have been created. We have seen wages rise by 14 per cent. We have seen statements made by the Labor Party that they were proud of the fact that while they were in government they pushed wages down as a percentage of GDP. We have seen that individual workers were worse off under a collectivist centralised wage-fixing system. The government has created 900,000 full time jobs and 800,000 part-time jobs. In the ALP's 13 years of government, they created only 707,000 jobs-that is, 707,000 jobs in 13 years as compared to this government's 1.7 million jobs in nine years-and only 188,000 of those jobs were full time; the rest were part time. By freeing up our workplace relations environment, we have been able to hypocreate new opportunities for people. With the not a sustained growth in our economy, we are able to offer real workplace security to people-that is, a real expectation that you will get a job when you leave school. I recall that, when I was in the Senate, there were something like one million unemployed people. School leavers looked with hopeless eyes at the prospect of getting a job. For young school leavers, the prospects were dismal. For young school leavers now, there is hope. The policies we have put in place allow the economy to be buoyant. They allow people to use their skills, and we see a greater participation of people than ever before. For the first time, we have more than 10 million employed people. The participation rate for women is at its highest-something like 65 per cent of women are participating in the work force. We have put enormous investment into women's education, and the country needs a return on that investment. That occurs when women participate in the work force and use their educational skills to add to the productivity of this nation. We have often heard that we are an ageing population-and we are. We are an ageing population because we are living longer and healthier lives, which is terrific, but also cause our birth rate has gone down to 1.7 children per family. Since the introduction of the baby bonus, that figure has gone from 1.73 to 1.77. But still we need greater participation from our people if we are to continue to see our productivity grow and to pay for the continuation of all the things that we consider to be our right in a society with such a high standard of living. That means paying for our pensions, for our health care system and for our education system. It means paying for all the things we regard as precious. In 1999, the International Year of Older Persons, I commissioned some research from Access Economics which showed that we can afford to do all of those things as long as we continue to see growth in our economy and increases in productivity. There are two things that will mean GDP will grow: an increase in the number of employees and an increase in productivity. Those are the two things that the Howard government has delivered in the nine years it has been in office. These are the two things which have sustained our economy and have led to a turnaround of the boom-bust mentality that we saw for so many years. When we had a bust, we would see a loss of jobs so great that, even when we saw a boom, employment did not catch up and the number of unemployed people continued to escalate. By freeing up workplace relations and putting in place this historic new system, we are giving this country the opportunity it needs to continue to deliver the services we all need and expect. It will enable people to enter the job market and have the fulfilling experience of working within the economy and contributing to it. It will give hope to people who have never had a prospect of a job-they too will be able to participate. When we bring together our policies to change and free up the workplace we will besee higher wages, a greater rate of participation by our citizens than ever before and more households with someone working, as distinct from households where children have been destined to live with a welfare mentality. These things all hinge on the reforms that have been put in place. At the beginning of the debate, Mr Beazley said the legislation was all about sacking. It is not. It is all about employing. It is all about hope. It is all about flexibility. It is all about being able to negotiate something that suits you. It is all about recognising that the individual is the most precious asset in our society and about freeing the individual to work in a way that suits that person, making a contribution to their family and to the nation. It is about ensuring we see productivity grow and that we are able to provide all the services that we will continue to need. It is all about showing people that this government is prepared not to look at a collectivist ideal where the individual is sacrificed, but where the individual is the most invigorated part of our society and is successful, bringing about that dual outcome-success for themselves and success for the nation. (Time expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Order! The discussion is now concluded. ANTI-TERRORISM BILL (No. 2) 2005 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Ruddock, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I move: That this bill be now read a second time. Yesterday this House passed amendments to clarify the terrorist act offences in part 5.3 of tion the Criminal Code. As I informed the House yesterday, the government would like all elements of the anti-terrorism legislation package to become law before Christmas. This second bill contains the remaining provisions to ensure that we have the toughest laws possible to prosecute those responsible should a terrorist attack occur. Second and of equal importance, the bill ensures we are in the strongest position possible to prevent new and emerging threats, to stop terrorists carrying out their intended acts. This bill has been the subject of extensive consultation. The Prime Minister first announced the proposals to strengthen Australia's counterterrorism laws on 8 September in advance of a special COAG meeting. The following day senior officials from the Commonwealth met with their state and territory counterparts to discuss the proposals. The special COAG meeting of 27 September provided an opportunity for the Prime Minister to discuss the proposals with premiers and chief ministers who agreed that there was a clear case for laws to be strengthened. The COAG agreement was followed by extensive consultation with the states and territories at officer level as well as directly between the Prime Minister and premiersand the chief ministers. This consultation process of almost two months has been very constructive and has yielded the positive result of an agreed position on the text of the bill introduced today. Control Orders and Preventative DetenMuch of the discussion has focused on the control orders and preventative detention regimes and their extensive safeguards. Firstly, in considering whether to apply for or issue a control order the personal circumstances of an individual will need to be balanced against the threat to the community. This does not mean that personal circumstances will outweigh the assessment of the threat, but it is recognised that both issues need to be taken into account. Under the control order regime: - an “interim” control order is made initially. The person the subject of the order may attend the court and make representations when the court decides to confirm, void or revoke the order; - the control order does not come into effect until the person is notified. - the person can apply for the order to be revoked, varied or declared void as soon as the person is notified that an order has been confirmed. - the person and their lawyer may have a copy of the grounds for making or varying the order; Under the preventative detention regime: - the order, as well as the treatment of the person detained, would be subject to judicial review. There is also built in merits review including when the police seek a continued preventative detention order. - At that time the person detained or their legal representative can provide the police with additional information concerning the preventative detention order. - The issuing authority is required to consider afresh the merits of making the order and to be satisfied, after taking into fence. account relevant information, including information provided to the police by the person subject to the order, that the ditions for the order are met. This includes any information that has become available since the initial preventative detention order was made. - the person detained may contact a lawyer, a family member… their employer… and another person at the discretion of the police officer; - each year, the Attorney-General would report to parliament on the operation of preventative detention orders - the regime will not apply to people under 16 and special rules will apply for people between the ages of 16 and 18 and people incapable of managing their own affairs. A number of members of the government have suggested that questioning of a person in preventative detention should be permitted-subject to normal safeguards. This was not the subject of COAG agreement reached in September but the government will examine this issue prior to the next COAG meeting and, if anything is to be considered arising from that, it will occur then. Advocating terrorism and sedition The bill also addresses those in our community who incite terrorist acts. It does this by expanding upon the Australian government's ability to proscribe terrorist organisations that advocate terrorism and also updates the sedition offence. The updated sedition offence will address problems with those who incite directly against other groups within our community. The sedition amendments are modernising the language of the provisions and are not a wholesale revision of the sedition ofHowever, given the considerable interest in the provisions, I would like to assure this conHouse that I will undertake to conduct with my department a review of the sedition offences. I would also note that honourable members will be aware that I announced on 12 October 2005 the establishment of the Security Legislation Review Committee. The committee will be chaired by the Honourable Simon Sheller AO QC, a recently retired NSW Supreme Court judge. As required by the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002, the review will focus on the existing counterterrorism laws. I would note here that it is possible for other matters to be referred to that committee, and I will be asking that committee to examine some issues relevant to individual advocacy which have been raised with me. But to return to today's matters ... the bill bolsters the existing offences dealing with funding terrorist organisations and financing individual terrorists. The new measures will facilitate the tracking of terrorist funds and also make it harder for terrorists to transfer funds across international borders. Law Enforcement and ASIO Powers Finally the bill extends the powers of police to stop, question and search, to all Commonwealth places and prescribed security zones to safeguard against terrorism. The AFP will be provided with a new notice to produce regime to ensure compliance with lawful requests for certain types of information. Finally the bill strengthens the regime relating to ASIO's powers, including enhancing various aspects of ASIO's special powers warrant regime … access to aircraft and vessel information … the offence for providing false or misleading information under an ASIO questioning warrant … and amends the relevant Customs legislation to broaden Customs powers for security and intelligence purposes. These measures complement others taken by the government to ensure that agencies are appropriately equipped and resourced to protect the Australian community. I can confirm that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, will move today to support a reference of the Anti-Terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2005 to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for consideration of the bill upon introduction in the House and to report on 28 November 2005. I commend the bill to the House and I table the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Bevis) adjourned. NA OPPORTUNITIES BILL 2005 Report from Main Committee Bill returned from Main Committee without amendment; certified copy of the bill presented. Ordered that this bill be considered immediately. Bill agreed to. Third Reading

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: As I was saying prior to question time, after winning office the New Zealand Prime Minister, Helen Clark, partially re-regulated the labour market. Even so, only a small list of minimum entitlements were included: a minimum adult wage, three weeks annual leave, 11 paid annual holidays, five days sick leave, three days bereavement leave and up to 13 weeks paid maternity leave. With this slight re-regulation, New Zealand still has a far less regulated system than the Australian system will be after our reforms come into place. If we go across to the other side of the world, to the United Kingdom, where the Labour Prime Minister inherited a system from a Conservative Prime Minister, we hear a similar story being told. The United Kingdom industrial relations system is also far more deregulated than ours will be, and they are reaping the benefits of those reforms, which the Labour Prime Minister, Tony Blair, accepted upon winning office. In 1997 Tony Blair said in his first speech to the United Kingdom Trade Union Congress: We are not going back to the days of industrial warfare, strikes without ballots, mass and flying pickets and secondary action ... … … … ... fairness at work starts with the chance of a job in the first place, because if we ... do not make Britain a country of successful businesses, a country where people want to set up and expand and a country that has the edge over our competitors, then we are betraying those we represent ... The British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, recognises that a job is a great start in life and, through a job, people can work their way out of any potential welfare dependency. By getting that first step into the labour market, various other career options can emerge for the person who was originally unemployed. In the United Kingdom the state has largely kept out of industrial relations, under the principle of ‘voluntarism'. Relatively recent changes have made a range of workplace relations matters subject to statutory regulation. Unlike Australia, the United Kingdom has never had awards. Since 1997, the Low Pay Commission has set the minimum wage in the UK. In many ways this body is a forerunner to the proposed Australian Fair Pay Commission included in this bill. There is, however, one major difference: the British government reserves the right to reject decisions made by the Low Pay Commission. This government through our reforms will not be able to reject the decisions of the new Fair Pay Commission. It is obvious that throughout this debate a lot of huff and puff has taken place-(Time expired)

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: It does seem a rather bizarre way to begin my contribution, but it will take only a minute for me to say that I am amazed on another matter to see the Attorney-General come into this place, introduce legislation of profound import and take just 10 minutes to read his speech into the Hansard. I must say that, given the importance of that legislation and the debate it has generated, it is consistent with the pattern that we have seen in this Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005 that the parliament is treated with such contempt. When you are making momentous changes of this kind, it is incumbent upon ministers to take the parliament seriously, at least for public display, even if they do regard the parliament as a rubber stamp for the executive. We have seen this pattern repeated over and over again, and it is becoming very galling not just for members of the opposition but for the community at large to see their elected representatives held in such disdain. I believe that Australians generally would want to see this government held to account on this bill, as on others, for setting aside the usual procedures and protocols of this parliament. NA
