Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I was not, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was speaking to the bill. Government Advertising

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: We learned this week that the bill for taxpayers from the government's industrial relations advertising campaign was $50 million, not the $30 million or $40 million the Prime Minister had fessed up to on radio$50 million and rising; over a million dollars a day being spent. With apologies to Winston Churchill, never before in the history of government advertising has so much money been hosed up against a wall by so few in so short a time. Fifty million dollars to produce full-page as which say, ‘Australia cannot afford to stand still'! This is not information: information would be something like telling Australians how to recognise the symptoms of bird flu; this is propaganda. And with the government so cheerfully taking a cigarette lighter to taxpayers' funds have come the stories of excess, like the man who was paid $6,000 just for a morning's work as an extra on a set. He was only going there to drop off his kids, he was not even used, and he says there were nine others like him-$60,000 of taxpayers' money straight down the gurgler. Then there were the call centre operators who were also paid to do nothing because they were rostered on a full six hours before the government's as even went to air! Taxpayers around Australia are no doubt wondering how such excesses can possibly happen. In the case of the advertising agency fees, it is all too simple. The ad agency get a percentage of everything they spend. In the case of this contract, the amount is a secret. But typically it is 10 to 15 per cent, so the more they spend the more they makebeautiful! And just who is the advertising agency with the contract for this $50 million IR campaign? It is none other than Dewey Horton, one of whose principals, Ted Horton, also does the Liberal Party's campaign advertising. Did the contract go out to tender? No. Could other agencies bid for it? No. Is the contract secret? Yes. Who awarded it? That would be the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications, a committee of Liberal Party MPs and ministers located deep within the bowels of the Prime Minister's department. Ted Horton is making a great deal of money from this campaign, as he no doubt has done from his previous work. And some people who make a lot of money sometimes do not want to pay all the tax that is owing on it. I am aware of reports that a Melbourne based advertising agency has provided documents to the tax office following a query by the tax office concerning payments to Mr Horton. I have also heard reports that Mr Horton has made payments to international accounts when working for overseas clients. The government must investigate this matter and tell the Australian people whether the Australian Taxation Office has sought documents from Ted Horton or any of his former employers or former or current clients as part of the high net worth individuals investigation or other routine inquiries. Were any of those queries or documents related to the issue of offshore payments to Mr Horton for work done either in Australia or overseas? Has Mr Horton been investigated by the tax office as part of its high net worth individuals investigation? If so, what are the results of that investigation? The Australian people are also entitled to some transparency surrounding the awarding of advertising contracts by the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications. The Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans, criticised the lack of openness concerning these contracts and said they contained the potential for corruption. He was absolutely right to do so. It is too cute by half that this massive, lucrative contract given out by Liberal Party insiders just happens to go to the Liberal Party's own advertising team. This week we also learned that Ted Horton had taken on Mark Pearson for the IR  ton work together on Liberal Party campaigns. Mark Pearson is no stranger to Liberal government largesse: he made a handy little $400,000 out of the GST ad campaign. The public are entitled to know how much  of taxpayers this time. The public want to know how these contracts are awarded. They want to see the documents. They want to know what checks the government has to ensure contracts do not go to tax avoiders. It is time to clean up this rotten insider dealing. Make the advertising contracts subject to the government's procurement policy and put them out for open tender and assessment on their merits, not on the basis of who has done the most to help the Liberal Party. Workplace Relations Ryan Electorate: Tourism

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Today in the parliament I spoke on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005. I was very delighted to speak on that because it is all about securing the future prosperity of this country and bringing jobs to the young people of Australia and indeed all Australians, particularly those Australians who live in my electorate of Ryan. It is a momentous bill and it is all about business. I want to continue that theme this afternoon but particularly in relation to the tourism industry-and I am delighted to see that the Minister for Small Business and Tourism is in the chamber as I speak. We have just heard the shadow minister for public accountability give another antibusiness diatribe. His contributions in this parliament are always wrapped in grubby attacks and below the belt verballing of companies that are doing legal business in this country. Tourism in this country is all about jobs and I want to refer to Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary in Fig Tree Pocket, which employs many Australians; indeed, many young Australians are employed there. Those at the sanctuary were delighted by the news this week about the prospects of receiving more Chinese tourists from mainland China, the People's Republic of China. Earlier this week the government announced that a significant number of Chinese will be able to come to this country, consistent with an agreement that the Australian government and the Chinese government have signed. The new agreement between the two governments, through the China National Tourism Administration, approved potentially 850 million to 900 million Chinese visiting this country. Of course, we do not expect that many to come here but we would be delighted with many hundreds of thousands coming, because they will continue to provide jobs in this country. The Approved Destination Status scheme-the ADS scheme-is a bilateral scheme which enables Chinese tourists to visit Australia on group tours. Australia was the first Western country to be designated as an approved destination for tourists from China. The new agreement was announced in China recently by Senator the Hon. Amanda Vanstone and very strongly supported by the Minister for Small Business and Tourism and her department: “This new agreement will mean an additional 855 million Chinese citizens will now be eligible to apply for a tourist visa to Australia, growing the pool of potential tourists considerably,” Fran ley, Minister for Small Business and Tourism, said ... This country is experiencing enormous growth. China is a nation that we consider very important to our bilateral relations and, with a free trade agreement being discussed at the moment between the two countries, this further reflects the enormous potential for business and for commerce to grow between our businesspeople and those entrepreneurs in a mainland China. The minister for tourism went on: China is the new tourism tiger in the playground. Millions of middle class Chinese with cash to spend are looking to travel. Within three years, the Chinese market is forecast to be our second largest in terms of its contribution to the Australian economy. I am delighted to play a small part in fostering exchanges and visits between our two countries in terms of Chinese businesspeople coming to this country and also to provide opportunities for Australian businesses, including those in my Ryan electorate, to engage in commercial relationships in China. China is currently the fifth largest source of tourists and it is forecast to be the second largest by 2013-14. Visitor arrivals from China are forecast to grow from 286,000almost 300,000-for 2004-05 to in excess of 1.1 million within the decade. This is an average annual growth of 16.5 per cent. The real market value of Chinese visitors in 2005 is forecast to be some $1.5 billion and it is forecast to increase to $5.9 billion by 2014. This is good for Australians because it is going to contribute to providing jobs throughout the country for our young people. It is going to provide opportunities for those in hospitality and in retail. I am sure that the opposition would support the government in this endeavour, because it is all about providing jobs for people in this country and, in my Baicase as the federal member for Ryan, providing as many opportunities as possible for people in Ryan to take on jobs. The hospitality sector, the retail sector and the tourism industry are very significant to this nation's economy. I encourage all members of the parliament to speak very strongly about this policy, about this initiative and about this agreement because it is in the interests of all Australians. (Time expired) Skills Shortage

Speaker: Mrs ELLIOT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise today to speak on behalf of the very many young people in this country who face a very limited choice because of the Howard government's refusal to address the skills crisis in this country-a skills crisis that is worsening all the time. This is the week in which we have seen the Howard government introducing its extreme attack on our industrial relations system. They want to strip workers of their rights and conditions and leave the most vulnerable unprotected in the workplace, and young Australians will be particularly at risk. I am very much concerned, particularly for the young people and, indeed, all the families within Richmond. The Prime Minster wants us to compete with low-wage economies like China and India by slashing Australian wages. This is economically irresponsible and will undermine our very way of life. Instead we need to compete with these economies by addressing our skills crisis and building the skills of Australian workers-that is where our focus should be. We are facing a skills crisis because we have been subjected to nine long years of a Howard government that refuses to properly invest in vocational education and training. This incompetence is affecting so many people within my electorate of Richmond. Many locals have been telling me that they desperately want to get employment, they want to get skilled but they cannot as the courses are not available for them because the federal Howard government will not properly fund our TAFEs. This decline in funding over the last nine years has meant that TAFEs-including those in my electorate of Richmond-are often forced to turn away potential students because there are no courses to place them in. I want to talk about some local examples, in particular Gregory Watts and Michael Gray. Both fellows want to upskill and get welding qualifications and, currently, the North Coast of New South Wales is suffering a skills shortage in metal fabrication and welding. Nearby there is a first-rate welding school at Wollongbar TAFE. So far, it sounds like Gregory and Michael are on the right track and making a good career decision. But they cannot actually get into a course longbar TAFE. Members might ask why it is they cannot get in there. They cannot because the Howard government is starving TAFEs of funds and, consequently, the welding school can open only during the day and not at night. Locals like Gregory and Michael, who have to work during the day to support themselves and their families, need to train at night and they cannot because that particular course is not available at night. I understand there are at least another 30 locals in this same position, many of whom have spoken to me because they really want to be able to do this welding course at Wollongbar TAFE and they are not able to. I understand there are also many local businesses that actually want to pay to have their workers upskilled in this course at this TAFE and they cannot. So what is the situation that we find ourselves in here? We have a shortage of welders in this area. We have local businesses that are willing to pay for this particular staff training. On the North Coast, we have youth unemployment at over 30 per cent, which is a huge amount. We also have one of the best welding schools in the state. We have this absurd situation where this school is sitting idle at night because of a lack of funding from the short-sighted Howard government. These locals are unable to access that course. Instead this government wants to bring in apprentices from overseas to satisfy the skills crisis. What are we supposed to be saying to locals like Michael and Gregory? What we are saying is, ‘We're not going to bother training you; we'd rather give your job to someone from another country.' This is an absurd situation. I believe we need to train Australians first. In Richmond we need to train locals first, such as Michael and Gregory, who desperately want to do this training. We should not be importing apprentices and workers from overseas to be filling these positions; we need to be training and at Wolskilling our young people first. In contrast, federal Labor has a blueprint for the training of young Australians. This blueprint will improve the competitiveness of our nation by building the skills of our young people so they can reach their potential, rather than removing their rights at work, as we are seeing the Howard government doing at the moment. Federal Labor will invest in schools and vocational education to offer young people better choices. We will help young people access better and more training more easily. We will create more real apprenticeships. Australians deserve a government that is serious about addressing our skills crisis and serious about investing in vocational educational and ing. There is only one way to give Australians real choice-by taking Labor's highskills road, not the Howard government's low-wage road. It is outrageous in an area like Richmond, as I said, with over 30 per cent youth unemployment. We need to be training our young people. (Time expired) Korumburra Primary School

Speaker: Mr BROADBENT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I had the great pleasure of attending Korumburra Primary School only a few days ago. It is a great school-this school rocks. Its award-winning choir was there on the morning to greet me at a major assembly for the whole school, as were teachers and parents. Its musical program was incredible. The choir sang I Had a Dream, led ably by Mrs Paproth. The choir came to a crescendo in I Had a Dream-and I know the member for MCEwen would remember the ABBA song I Had a Dream of 25 years ago. Fran Bailey-I do.

Speaker: Mr BROADBENT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: It was a great song, beautifully presented by these very young primary school students, and when they went into the key change you just had to grab hold of the moment and feel a part of it. Mrs Paproth was thrilled to bits. Because of a part of my background, I recognised the key change and that they went up a semi-tone. It was absolutely magnificent to be there. When I say this school rocks, they really did rock. It was just fantastic, as was the enthusiasm of the teachers. For what reason was I there? I was there as the federal member to praise the Reading Challenge of the Premier of Victoria and to make a few presentations. We talked about Investing in Our Schools, but then what did they do? The whole school sang I am Australian, with harmony coming from the choir and with five teachers playing guitar-it was trainabsolutely sensational. The Minister for Small Business and Tourism, the member for MCEwen, did not believe me when I said Korumburra Primary School rocks! It really does, and they are academically great achievers. Every member of one class completed the Reading Challenge set by the Premier. However, my difficulty was that the children then asked me in front of everybody what my favourite childhood book was. My favourite-I know every member here, joining us in this parliament this evening, will remember this one, and I thank all the members for joining us this evening as we wind up the week-was Little Toot. I explained to them why mine was Little Toot. Little Toot had three or four goes at getting where he was going. He got to the mountain a couple of times and fell back, and had another go and fell back, and had another go and fell back. I was explaining to the young students how important it is never to give up and to be persistent and to always keep trying. Even if you are not the best book reader, it is important to have a go at reading a book, and they did. Of course these children-and I know every member in this House feels exactly the same way as I do-are our future. The teachers who teach them have a heavy responsibility for what they do. Especially the mums who are in this House tonight, and perhaps the future mums who are in this House tonight, will feel that responsibility and know the challenges that their children went through, be they health challenges or academic challenges or just growing-up challenges. So a heavy responsibility has been given to Korumburra Primary School, their principal and their teachers, and they are working through it. This government also has provided money right across Victoria for Investing in Our Schools. It was a tremendous pleasure for me to go to Elizabeth Street Primary School and deliver some money to them. It has been a difficult school in Moe for years. They were just absolutely beside themselves to get their money. At the Nyora Primary School I was able to sit under a 100-year-old oak tree and think of the generations that have gone through the school. I was able to congratulate them on a citizenship program that they had invested in. I have already told the House about Korumburra Primary School. The other day the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, visited the Blackwood Annexe and took some Investing in Our Schools money down there. The Blackwood Annexe is absolutely sensational. So sometimes members of parliament have great days, and the great day I had was when Korumburra Primary School rocked. Capricornia Electorate: Murray Lagoon

Speaker: Ms LIVERMORE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: What a delight it is to follow on from a member talking with such enthusiasm about something that happened in his electorate. I too would like to use my time this afternoon to talk about a project which, while it has not yet taken place, I have very great enthusiasm for and to which I wish to give my strongest possible support. I am talking about an application that is currently with the government, under the Community Water Grants scheme, to rejuvenate and revitalise the Murray Lagoon in Rockhampton. Visitors to Rockhampton, and indeed the residents of Rockhampton, know that the botanical gardens area of our city is an absoidea lute jewel. It is a very special place, of which we are all very proud. The Rockhampton Botanical Gardens is bordered by Murray Lagoon and it is also adjacent to the Rockhampton Golf Club. The application currently before the government seeking $50,000 from the Community Water Grants scheme is a joint project between the Rockhampton Golf Club and the Central Queensland University to do a feasibility study into the harvesting and filtering of stormwater and recycled water through the wetlands and into Murray Lagoon. As I said, the botanical gardens, the golf club and the Murray Lagoon area is a real jewel in Rockhampton city; but over the last few years, because of the extremely dry conditions we have been experiencing right around the country, the wetlands, the Murray Lagoon area, has become seriously depleted of water and has deteriorated significantly. In this once beautiful area that was an important habitat for fish, turtles, native birds and other forms of wildlife-it was a very important ecosystem-the water has gradually receded until it is now almost totally dry. It is really just an area covered with noxious weeds, introduced plant species and feral animals. The poor pelicans, native birds and other species are being forced into a smaller and smaller area, and it is a very sad thing to see when this is such a special and beautiful place. The application that is before the government at the moment is a fantastic project. It is a classic win-win situation which has the support of a great number of stakeholders in Rockhampton. I have already mentioned the project partners CQU and the Rockhampton Golf Club, but it is also supported by the Environmental Protection Agency, the department of natural resources and the Rockhampton City Council, among others. The is to design a best-practice system to harvest and filter stormwater and treated effluent through artificial and enhanced natural wetlands. Now we have a situation where Murray Lagoon is dry and the Rockhampton Golf Club would like to have access to a source of water to do its own irrigation. We have got a situation where stormwater and treated effluent is being pumped back into the Fitzroy River by the Rockhampton City Council. The Fitzroy River empties into the Great Barrier Reef, so anything that we can do to divert that stormwater and treated effluent going to be helping the water quality in the Fitzroy River and also on the Great Barrier Reef. We are looking at the feasibility of verting that water into wetlands and into Murray Lagoon. It will reduce effluent discharge into the river and supply irrigation water to the golf course and the botanical gardens, and the publicity that this fantastic project will receive from local media outlets-who have indicated their very strong support-will get the message of water reuse and water conservation throughout the whole community. There is also an opportunity for Indigenous youth to be involved through a training project in conjunction with this project. So give this project my very strongest support. It is a fantastic example of the kind of munity spirit we have in Rockhampton, where people get together to collaborate on something that will be good on so many levels and once again return Murray Lagoon to being a fantastic asset to our city. (Time pired) Second World War: 60th Anniversary

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: We have been considering in the course of this week some of the very real challenges that confront Australia today, in the shape of terrorism and of disease in the form of avian flu. But the greatest challenge that our nation has ever faced and the greatest threat that there has been to its security and the liberties of Australians was during the Second World War, which ended 60 years ago in August. This year we have been celebrating and commemorating the end of that war. Tomorrow, 95 veterans and widows of veterans of the Second World War will be presented by me and General Peter Cosgrove with the World War II commemorative medals which the Commonwealth government is has struck and which are being presented to approximately 250,000 veterans of that war. This ceremony will be held at Victoria Bardiracks in Sydney, one of the oldest military establishments in Australia. The Australian Army band, under the directorship of Major Andrea Davey, will be playing, and in addition to the 95 veterans and widows there will be another 300 family members and friends. It will be a wonderful occasion and a very fitting way to remember the sacrifice of all those whose served Australia in the Second World War and to honour those who have survived the 60 years with the presentation of the medal. The veterans and their widows will be I joined by representatives from the Rose Bay RSL, the Bondi Junction-Waverley RSL, the com- Paddington-Woollahra RSL and the Clovelly RSL, which are the principal returned servicemen's organisations in my electorate. Earlier this year the federal government made funds available to the Bondi JunctionexWaverly RSL and the Rose Bay RSL under the program Saluting Their Service 2005, which gave the means and the wherewithal to many community organisations to hold their own celebrations-mostly in Augustto commemorate the end of the Second World War. At the ceremony tomorrow we will be presenting these medals to the veterans, many of whom are very old friends of mine. Winston Summerhayes-better known as Buster Summerhayes-a great doctor in the eastern suburbs of Sydney, was for many years the honorary medical adviser to the City Tattersalls Harriers in Centennial Park. Buster Summerhayes will be there and fitter, probably, than most of the younger people. He is a great athlete. My father-in-law, Tom Hughes, who is of course a former member of this parliament, will also be there. Tom served in the Air Force in the Second World War and he is still at the peak of his forensic powers as he approaches his 82nd birthday at the end of November. It will also be a great honour for us all in Wentworth to have General Peter Cosgrove at our ceremony. He retired as Chief of the Defence Force in 2005 and is one of the most distinguished servicemen in Australia in modern times. He became a national figure following his appointment as Commander of International Forces East Timor, where he led the Australian force that ensured the safety and security of that fledging nation. He was responsible, along with the men and women who served under him, for overseeing East Timor's transition to independence during what was a very tense and uncertain period both in East Timor and, more widely, in Indonesia. Tomorrow, Wentworth will remember the men and women who defended Australia in the Second World War. Their example of heroism and commitment will be in the forefront of our minds, as I am sure it has been in the forefront of the minds of all Australians, especially during this year, the 60th anniversary of the end of our greatest struggle-the end of the war when we were most at threat and the end of the war when many Australians paid the greatest sacrifice in our defence. (Time expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 5 pm, the debate is interrupted. House adjourned at 5.00 pm NA The following notices were given: Mr Abbott to move: That standing orders 31 (automatic adjournment of the House) and 33 (limit on business after 9.30 pm) be suspended for the sitting on Monday, 7 November and Tuesday, 8 November 2005. Ms King to move: That this House: (1) acknowledges the important contribution made by the manufacturing sector to rural economies specifically and the Australian economy generally; (2) notes that: (a) the October Australian Industry Group Pricewaterhouse Coopers Australian Performance of Manufacturing Index shows the third decline of manufacturing activity in Australia in four months; (b) the Australian automobile component parts manufacturing sector is under threat from cheap imports produced in countries with low wage levels and poor or non-existent occupational health and safety safeguards; and (c) necessary research and design support to encourage the development of new processes and products is not available to manufacturers; and (3) calls on the Government to: (a) appoint a Minister with specific responsibility for manufacturing; and (b) develop a plan to secure Australia's manufacturing future including investment in research and development, skills training and infrastructure.
